text:
Hi, how do you merge a list of Tuple in a single Tuple?

`merge((Tuple((a,a)) for a=1:3)...)` does not work

elements.text: Hi, how do you merge a list of Tuple in a single Tuple?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

```julia> a = [Tuple((a,a)) for a=1:3]
3-element Vector{Tuple{Int64, Int64}}:
 (1, 1)
 (2, 2)
 (3, 3)

julia> Tuple(Iterators.flatten(a))
(1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 3)```
I think this gets you what you want.

elements.text:
julia> a = [Tuple((a,a)) for a=1:3]
3-element Vector{Tuple{Int64, Int64}}:
 (1, 1)
 (2, 2)
 (3, 3)

julia> Tuple(Iterators.flatten(a))
(1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 3)
I think this gets you what you want.

text: :slightly_smiling_face: I was typing that in too .. go with ^

elements.text: I was typing that in too .. go with ^

text: having `merge` work with tuples seems reasonable to me

elements.text: work with tuples seems reasonable to me

text: `merge` for dictionaries overrides keys though, so it's not the same as just concatenation

elements.text: for dictionaries overrides keys though, so it's not the same as just concatenation

text: tuples have no keys to override, do you mean that `merge` should only apply where something may be overriden (merging two dicts with distinct keys does not override)?

elements.text: tuples have no keys to override, do you mean that
should only apply where something may be overriden (merging two dicts with distinct keys does not override)?

text: I'd recommend against `tuple((a...)...)` unless all elements of `a` always have the same size - can lead to A LOT of tuple methods to be compiled...

elements.text: always have the same size - can lead to A LOT of tuple methods to be compiled...

text: the `Iterators.flatten` approach is definitely more sound

elements.text: I'd recommend against tuple((a...)...) unless all elements of a always have the same size - can lead to A LOT of tuple methods to be compiled...
No, the beauty of this is that it won't create any intermediate tuples. Of course, overspecialization will still be an issue if the total number of elements in
is large, but then you probably shouldn't use tuples in the first place

text: ah yes, I mentally talked about the wrong dots - should be `unless a always has the same size and is small`

elements.text: ah yes, I mentally talked about the wrong dots - should be
unless a always has the same size and is small
